required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Apneic Oxygenation Including Precipitous Intubations During RSI in the ED
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial of Apneic Oxygenation Including Precipitous Intubations During RSI in the Emergency Department

lead_sponsor.agency: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

clinical_study.source: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

brief_summary.textblock: This RCT is testing the efficacy of apneic oxygenation during endotracheal intubation in the emergency department. Currently the standard practice in the ED when performing endotracheal intubation is that some providers use apneic oxygenation (the application of a nasal cannula at 15LPM) throughout the intubation procedure, while others do not apply apneic oxygenation. Initial literature in the operating room showed that apneic oxygenation helps prevent desaturation during the procedure. However, the latest literature conducted in critical care settings (one study in the ICU and one in the ED) questions the efficacy of this intervention in critically ill patients; however, no harm has been shown. Our study aims to test this intervention further by adding in a special subset of patients that was excluded from prior studies, precipitous intubations, or those patients that have to be intubated quickly and cannot have adequate pre-oxygenation. We hypothesize that apneic oxygenation will be more efficacious in this subset than in the overall ED population. We will randomize patients requiring endotracheal intubation into intervention (apneic oxygenation) and control (no apneic oxygenation). We will measure the lowest arterial oxygen saturation from the start of the intubation procedure through 2 minutes after intubation is complete.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Time between neuromuscular blockade and 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
primary_outcome.description: Lowest oxygen saturation between overall control and intervention groups

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time between neuromuscular blockade and 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
secondary_outcome.description: Lowest oxygen saturation between control and intervention groups that did not receive adequate pre-oxygenation only

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time between neuromuscular blockade and 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
secondary_outcome.description: Lowest oxygen saturation between control and intervention groups that did receive

secondary_outcome.measure: Difference in baseline and final oxygen saturation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Decision to intubate through 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation

secondary_outcome.measure: Difference in oxygen saturation before and after apneic period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Initiation of neuromuscular blockade through 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
Initiation of neuromuscular blockade through 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients who desaturate below 90%

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first attempt at intubation through completion of endotracheal intubation procedure, approximately 2 minutes.
secondary_outcome.description: number of times laryngoscope is placed into the mouth in an attempt to pass an endotracheal tube

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first attempt at intubation through completion of endotracheal intubation procedure, approximately 2 minutes.
secondary_outcome.description: A second physician had to attempt intubation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first attempt at intubation through completion of endotracheal intubation procedure, approximately 2 minutes.
secondary_outcome.description: The operator needed to change or add equipment to facilitate intubation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first attempt at intubation through entire ED stay, approximately 6 hours.
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of intubations that resulted in the endotracheal tube being placed in the esophagus

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Initiation of neuromuscular blockade to 2 minutes after completion of endotracheal intubation
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of became hypotensive at any point during the intubation procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within 24 hours after intubation procedure was complete
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients that had evidence of aspiration
Number of days patient is hospitalized

intervention.description: Providing oxygenation through nasal cannula during the apneic phase of endotracheal intubation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The inclusion criteria for our study will include patients 18 years or older who require emergent endotracheal intubation utilizing rapid sequence intubation (RSI) in the Emergency Department with first attempt taken by a resident or attending physician working in the emergency department. This includes Emergency Medicine attending physicians and residents as well as non-Emergency Medicine rotators (e.g.., Internal Medicine residents who are rotating through the Emergency Department).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exclusion criteria include patients who are in cardiac arrest, or if the patient received any positive pressure ventilation (i.e, BPAP, CPAP, BVM) in the emergency department before RSI.
